proscene
Interface PSMouseGrabber

All Known Implementing Classes:
PSInteractiveCameraFrame, PSInteractiveFrame
public interface PSMouseGrabber

Interface for objects that grab mouse focus in a PScene.

PSMouseGrabber are objects which react to the mouse cursor, usually when it hovers over them.

How does it work ?

All the created PSMouseGrabbers are grouped in a mouse grabber pool. The PScene parse this pool, calling all the PSMouseGrabbers' checkIfGrabsMouse(int, int, PSCamera) methods that setGrabsMouse(boolean) if desired (method calls should actually be performed on concrete class instances such as PSInteractiveFrame).

When a PSMouseGrabber grabsMouse(), it becomes the PScene.mouseGrabber(). All the mouse events are then transmitted to it instead of being normally processed. This continues while grabsMouse() (updated using checkIfGrabsMouse(int, int, PSCamera)) returns true.

If you want to (temporarily) disable a specific PSMouseGrabbers, you can remove it from this pool using removeFromMouseGrabberPool().

Field Detail

MouseGrabberPool

static final java.util.List<PSMouseGrabber> MouseGrabberPool
Method Detail

getMouseGrabberPool

java.util.List<PSMouseGrabber> getMouseGrabberPool()
Returns a list containing references to all the active PSMouseGrabbers.

Used by the PScene to parse all the PSMouseGrabbers and to check if any of them grabsMouse() checkIfGrabsMouse(int, int, PSCamera).

You should not have to directly use this list. Use removeFromMouseGrabberPool() and addInMouseGrabberPool() to modify this list.

See Also:
getMouseGrabberPool()

checkIfGrabsMouse

void checkIfGrabsMouse(int x,
                       int y,
                       PSCamera camera)
Called by the PScene before they test if the PSMouseGrabber grabsMouse(). Should setGrabsMouse(boolean) according to the mouse position.

This is the core method of the PSMouseGrabber. Its goal is to update the grabsMouse() flag according to the mouse and PSMouseGrabber current positions, using setGrabsMouse(boolean).

grabsMouse() is usually set to true when the mouse cursor is close enough to the PSMouseGrabber position. It should also be set to false when the mouse cursor leaves this region in order to release the mouse focus.

x and y are the mouse cursor coordinates ((0,0) corresponds to the upper left corner).

A typical implementation will look like:

// (posX,posY) is the position of the PSMouseGrabber on screen.
// Here, distance to mouse must be less than 10 pixels to activate the MouseGrabber.
setGrabsMouse( PApplet.sqrt((x-posX)*(x-posX) + (y-posY)*(y-posY)) < 10);

If the PSMouseGrabber position is defined in 3D, use the camera parameter, corresponding to the calling PScene PSCamera. Project on screen and then compare the projected coordinates:

PVector proj = new PVector (camera.projectedCoordinatesOf(myPSMouseGrabber.frame().position());
setGrabsMouse((PApplet.abs(x-proj.x) < 5) && (PApplet.(y-proj.y) < 2)); // Rectangular region

mousePressEvent

void mousePressEvent(java.awt.event.MouseEvent event,
                     PSCamera camera)
Callback method called when the PSMouseGrabber grabsMouse() and a mouse button is pressed.

The PSMouseGrabber will typically start an action or change its state when a mouse button is pressed. mouseMoveEvent(MouseEvent, PSCamera) (called at each mouse displacement) will then update the PSMouseGrabber accordingly and mouseReleaseEvent(MouseEvent, PSCamera) (called when the mouse button is released) will terminate this action.

mouseMoveEvent

void mouseMoveEvent(java.awt.event.MouseEvent event,
                    PSCamera camera)
Callback method called when the PSMouseGrabber grabsMouse() and the mouse is moved while a button is pressed.

This method will typically update the state of the PSMouseGrabber from the mouse displacement. See the mousePressEvent(MouseEvent, PSCamera) documentation for details.

mouseReleaseEvent

                       PSCamera camera)
